title.value: Catalyzing next-generation Artificial Intelligence through NeuroAI
title.justification: This is the main title of the research paper as provided in the document.
title.quote: Catalyzing next-generation Artificial Intelligence through NeuroAI

extractions.description: This paper discusses the intersection of neuroscience and artificial intelligence, proposing that advancements in AI can be accelerated by drawing inspiration from neural computations and behaviors observed in animals. It introduces the concept of an 'embodied Turing test' for AI models to measure their performance against the adaptive, flexible, and efficient behaviors of animals.

type.justification: The paper primarily discusses conceptual frameworks and proposes new directions for research rather than presenting experimental results.
type.quote: We propose that to accelerate progress in AI, we must invest in fundamental research in NeuroAI.

name.justification: The paper explicitly introduces and discusses 'NeuroAI' as a primary research field combining neuroscience and artificial intelligence.
name.quote: The emerging field of NeuroAI, at the intersection of neuroscience and AI, is based on the premise that a better understanding of neural computation will reveal fundamental ingredients of intelligence and catalyze the next revolution in AI.

name.justification: The paper discusses reinforcement learning as a key aspect of AI inspired by neuroscience.
name.quote: Similarly, the development of reinforcement learning was directly inspired by insights into animal behavior and neural activity during learning.

name.justification: Neuroscience findings on visual processing circuits have inspired convolutional networks, which are pivotal in computer vision.
name.quote: Later, the Nobel-prize winning work of David Hubel and Torsten Wiesel on visual processing circuits in the cat neocortex inspired the deep convolutional networks that have catalyzed the recent revolution in modern AI.

name.justification: The original Turing test, focusing on conversational abilities, is a significant aspect of Natural Language Processing.
name.quote: In 1950, Alan Turing proposed the 'imitation game' as a test of a machine’s ability to exhibit intelligent behavior indistinguishable from that of a human.

name.justification: The paper discusses the capabilities of modern large language models in the context of passing the original Turing test.
name.quote: However, a class of modern AI systems called 'large language models' can now engage in surprisingly cogent conversations.

is_contributed.justification: The paper does not contribute a new large language model but discusses existing ones.
is_contributed.quote: However, a class of modern AI systems called 'large language models' can now engage in surprisingly cogent conversations.

is_executed.justification: The paper does not execute any large language models; it references their capabilities conceptually.
is_executed.quote: In part, their success reveals how easily we can be tricked into imputing intelligence, agency, and even consciousness to our interlocutor.

is_compared.justification: The paper compares large language models' capabilities with human conversational abilities in the context of the Turing test.
is_compared.quote: Impressive though these systems are, because they are not grounded in real-world experiences, they nonetheless continue to struggle with many basic aspects of causal reasoning and physical common-sense.

referenced_paper_title.justification: This is the relevant paper title mentioned in the context of discussing large language models.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Brown, T. et al. Language models are few-shot learners. Adv. Neural Inf. Process. Syst. 33, 1877–1901 (2020).
